an3.33:4.1: Then Venerable Sāriputta went up to the Buddha,
an3.33:4.2: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an3.33:4.6: maybe both in brief and in detail.
an3.33:4.7: But it’s hard to find anyone who understands.”
an3.33:4.8: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One! May the Buddha teach Dharma in brief, in detail, and both in brief and in detail.
an3.33:4.9: There will be those who understand the teaching!”
an3.33:5.1: “So, Sāriputta, you should train like this:
an3.33:5.2: ‘There’ll be no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for all external stimuli; and we’ll live having achieved the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where ego, possessiveness, and tendency to conceit are no more.’
an3.33:6.1: When a mendicant has no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no ego, possessiveness, or tendency to conceit for all external stimuli; and they live having attained the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where ego, possessiveness, and tendency to conceit are no more—
an3.33:6.3: a mendicant who has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.
an3.33:6.4: And Sāriputta, this is what I was referring to in ‘The Way to the Beyond’, in ‘The Questions of Udaya’ when I said:
an3.33:8.3: This, I declare, is liberation by final knowledge,
